searchDocs.title: Columnâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> type Column = {any}

searchDocs.title: Archetypeâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> interface Archetype { id:Â number types:Â {Entity} type:Â string entities:Â {Entity} columns:Â {Column} columnsMap:Â {[Entity]:Â Column} } Represents the internal storage of the ECS. For more information on Archetypes, read here.

searchDocs.title: Listenerâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> type Listener = ( entity:Â Entity, id:Â Id<T>, value:Â T, oldArchetype:Â Archetype )Â â†’Â () A callback type used in World:added and World:changed.

searchDocs.title: rangeâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:range( rangeBegin:Â number,-- The id to start at rangeEnd:Â number?-- The optional id to end at ) â†’Â () Enforces that entities created will have ids between the given range. world:range(1000, 5000) local entity = world:entity() print(entity) -- Will be >= 1000 and < 5000

searchDocs.title: queryâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:query( ...:Â Id-- The Components to query for ) â†’Â Query-- The Query object Creates a Query object to iterate over all entities with the given components, returning the entity id and values of each component. TIP Queries can do much more! See Query to see the additional methods you can chain together. for id, health, position in world:query(Health, Position):with(Enemy) do -- ... end

searchDocs.title: eachâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:each( id:Â Id-- The Component Id ) â†’Â ()Â â†’Â Entity-- An iterator that returns all relevant entities Allows for the iteration over all entities with the given component. local Component = world:component() for id in world:each(Component) do -- ... end

searchDocs.title: childrenâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:children( parent:Â Entity-- The Parent Entity ) â†’Â ()Â â†’Â Entity-- An iterator that returns all relevant entities Allows for the iteration over all entities that are a child of the given entity. for child in world:children(parent) do -- ... end

searchDocs.title: setâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:set( entity:Â Entity,-- The Entity Id id:Â Id<T>,-- The Component Id to set data:Â T ) â†’Â () Assigns a value to a component on the given entity, adding the component if the entity does not already have it. local Apples = world:component() local Eats = world:component() local Name = world:component() local entity = world:entity() world:set(entity, Name, "Bob") world:set(entity, Jecs.pair(Eats, Apples), 10) -- Bob ate 10 apples!

searchDocs.title: addâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:add( entity:Â Entity,-- The Entity Id id:Â Id<T>-- The Component Id to add ) â†’Â () Adds a component to the given entity. local Enemy = world:component() local Dislikes = world:component() local Player = world:component() local player = world:entity() world:add(player, Player) local entity = world:entity() world:add(entity, Enemy) world:add(entity, Jecs.pair(Dislikes, player))

searchDocs.title: getâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:get( entity:Â Entity,-- The Entity Id a:Â Id<A>,-- The first Component b:Â Id<B>?,-- The second Component c:Â Id<C>?,-- The third Component d:Â Id<D>?-- The fourth Component ) â†’Â ( A?, B?, C?, D? ) Retrieves the value(s) of up to 4 components, returning nil if the component is a tag or not present on the entity. local Health = world:component() local entity = world:entity() world:set(entity, Health, 100) local health: number? = world:get(entity, Health) print(health) -- Output: 100

searchDocs.title: addedâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:added( component:Â Id,-- The Component to listen for fn:Â Listener-- The function to call when a component is added ) â†’Â ()Â â†’Â ()-- A function to cleanup the listener Sets a callback that is invoked when the given component is added to an entity.

searchDocs.title: changedâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:changed( component:Â Id,-- The Component to listen for fn:Â Listener-- The function to call when a component's value is changed ) â†’Â ()Â â†’Â ()-- A function to cleanup the listener Sets a callback that is invoked when the given component's value is changed on an entity.

searchDocs.title: removedâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:removed( id:Â Id,-- The Component to listen for fn:Â ( entity:Â Entity, id:Â Id, deleted:Â boolean? )Â â†’Â ()-- The function to call when a component is removed ) â†’Â ()Â â†’Â ()-- A function to cleanup the listener Sets a callback that is invoked when the given component is removed from an entity.

searchDocs.title: hasâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:has( entity:Â Entity,-- The Entity Id a:Â Id,-- The first Component b:Â Id?,-- The second Component c:Â Id?,-- The third Component d:Â Id?-- The fourth Component ) â†’Â boolean Checks if up to 4 components are present on an entity, returningtrue if the entity has all 4 components or false if the entity does not have at least one. local Enemy = world:component() local entity = world:entity() world:add(entity, Enemy) local isEnemy: boolean = world:has(entity, Enemy) print(isEnemy) -- Output: true

searchDocs.title: targetâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:target( entity:Â Entity,-- The Entity Id relation:Â Id,-- The first element of a pair nth::Â number? ) â†’Â Id?-- The target, or the second element of a pair Given a relation, this will return the target of the nth relationship of the entity, where the first element of a pair is the relation and the second element of a pair is the target. local ChildOf = Jecs.ChildOf local Character = world:component() local Player = world:component() for entity in world:query(Character) do local player: Entity? = world:target(entity, ChildOf) print(world:has(player, Player)) -- Output: true end local Likes = world:component() local Name = Jecs.Name local Wildcard = Jecs.Wildcard for id, name in world:query(Name, pair(Likes, Wildcard)) do local nth = 0 local likes: Entity? = world:target(entity, Likes, nth) while likes do local friendsName: string? = world:get(likes, Name) print(`{name} likes {friendsName}`) nth += 1 likes = world:target(entity, Likes, nth) end end

searchDocs.title: parentâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:parent( entity:Â Entity-- The Entity Id ) â†’Â Id? Returns the parent of an entity, where the parent is the target of aChildOf relationship, or nil if there is no relationship pair. local ChildOf = Jecs.ChildOf local Character = world:component() local Player = world:component() for entity in world:query(Character) do local player: Entity? = world:parent(entity) print(world:has(player, Player)) -- Output: true end

searchDocs.title: entityâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:entity( id:Â number?-- The id to spawn the entity at ) â†’Â Entity-- The Entity Id Spawns a new entity, at the specified id if given.

searchDocs.title: removeâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:remove( entity:Â Entity,-- The Entity Id id:Â Id-- The component to remove ) â†’Â () Removes a component from the given entity.

searchDocs.title: deleteâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:delete( entity:Â Entity-- The Entity Id ) â†’Â () Deletes an entity, as well as all of it's components and relationships.

searchDocs.title: clearâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:clear( entity:Â Entity-- The Entity Id ) â†’Â () Clears all of the components and relationships from the given entity, but does not delete the entity. Instead, you can use World:delete to delete an entity and all of it's components.

searchDocs.title: existsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:exists( entity:Â Entity-- The Entity Id ) â†’Â boolean Given an entity id, returns true if the id exists in the world, or false, disregarding whether or not the entity is alive.

searchDocs.title: containsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:contains( entity:Â Entity-- The Entity Id ) â†’Â boolean Given an entity id, returns true if the id exists and is alive in the world, or false.

searchDocs.title: cleanupâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:cleanup() â†’Â () Cleans the world of empty archetypes. The interval at which you should call this method varies per application, and you should profile your application to determine this interval.

searchDocs.title: componentâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> World:component() â†’Â Component Creates a new component. TIP Components are also entities in Jecs, where the first 256 entity ids are reserved for components.

searchDocs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
searchDocs.content: Frequently Asked Questions Looks empty ðŸ‘€. Want to contribute some questions and answers? Click "Edit this page"!

searchDocs.title: archetypesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Query:archetypes() â†’Â {Archetype} Returns an array of Archetypes compatible with the query.

searchDocs.title: withâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Query:with( ...:Â Id-- The Components to filter for ) â†’Â Query Extends the query to filter for entities with the given component(s).

searchDocs.title: withoutâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Query:without( ...:Â Id-- The Components to filter for ) â†’Â Query Extends the query to filter for entities without the given component(s).

searchDocs.title: iterâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Query:iter() â†’Â ()Â â†’Â ( Id, ...:Â any ) A method for the old Luau type solver to fix the types for the query.

searchDocs.title: iterating over Queryâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> for Id,Â ...any in Query do Iterating over a Query will return the Entity Id, followed by the values of your components, or nil if the component has no value.

searchDocs.title: cachedâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Query:cached() â†’Â Query Returns a cached query. CAUTION A cached query is meant to be created once, and then used many times. Avoid creating a cached query in your actual systems, as to not create a cached query every frame. local function system(world: World) local enemies = world :query(Health, Position) :with(Enemy) :cached() return function() for id, health, position in enemies do -- ... end end end

searchDocs.title: hasâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Query:has( entity:Â Entity-- The Entity Id ) â†’Â boolean Returns true if the query has the given entity, or false.

searchDocs.title: Entityâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> type Entity = number An alias for Jecs.Id.

searchDocs.title: Idâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> type Id = number An Id represents an Entity, a Component, or a Pair. In Jecs, it is typed as { __T: T } to preserve types on Entities/Components, though it is essentially just a number.

searchDocs.title: Pairâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> type Pair = number Represents a relationship, where the first element is the relation, and the second element is the target. You can create pairs with Jecs.pair.

searchDocs.title: Componentâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> type Component = number An alias for Jecs.Id.

searchDocs.title: OnAddâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.OnAdd: Id A Component Trait for setting a hook onto a Component, which will run when the Component has been added to an Entity. local Transform: Id<vector> = world:component() world:set(Transform, Jecs.OnAdd, function(entity: Entity, id: Id<T>, data: T) -- `Transform` has been added to `entity` end)

searchDocs.title: OnRemoveâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.OnRemove: Id A Component Trait for setting a hook onto a Component, which will run when the Component has been removed from an Entity. local Transform: Id<vector> = world:component() world:set(Transform, Jecs.OnRemove, function(entity: Entity, id: Id<T>) -- `Transform` has been removed from `entity` end)

searchDocs.title: OnChangeâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.OnChange: Id A Component Trait for setting a hook onto a Component, which will run when the data of a Component has been changed on an Entity. local Transform: Id<vector> = world:component() world:set(Transform, Jecs.OnChange, function(entity: Entity, id: Id<T>, data: T) -- `Transform` on `entity` has been changed to `data` end)

searchDocs.title: Wildcardâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.Wildcard: Id An Id used for Wildcard Queries. local Likes = world:component() local Name = Jecs.Name local Wildcard = Jecs.Wildcard for id, name in world:query(Name, pair(Likes, Wildcard)) do local nth = 0 local likes: Entity? = world:target(entity, Likes, nth) while likes do local friendsName: string? = world:get(likes, Name) print(`{name} likes {friendsName}`) nth += 1 likes = world:target(entity, Likes, nth) end end

searchDocs.title: ChildOfâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.ChildOf: Id An Id used for Parent-Child hierarchies using Relationships. local ChildOf = Jecs.ChildOf local Character = world:component() local Player = world:component() for entity in world:query(Character) do local player: Entity? = world:parent(entity) print(world:has(player, Player)) -- Output: true end

searchDocs.title: OnDeleteâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.OnDelete: Id A Cleanup Condition which executes when the Entity is deleted. This is meant to be used with Jecs.Remove and Jecs.Delete to implement Cleanup Traits.

searchDocs.title: OnDeleteTargetâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.OnDeleteTarget: Id A Cleanup Condition for Relationships which executes when the target of the relationship is deleted, where the target is the second element of a pair. This is meant to be used with Jecs.Remove and Jecs.Delete to implement Cleanup Traits.

searchDocs.title: Deleteâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.Delete: Id When used as apart of a Cleanup Trait, it will delete all entities with the relevant id. local OnDelete = Jecs.OnDelete local Delete = Jecs.Delete local Component = world:component() world:add(Component, Jecs.pair(OnDelete, Delete)) local entity = world:entity() world:add(entity, Component) world:delete(Component) -- `entity` will be deleted.

searchDocs.title: Removeâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.Remove: Id When used as apart of a Cleanup Trait, it will delete all entities with the relevant id. local OnDelete = Jecs.OnDelete local Remove = Jecs.Remove local Component = world:component() world:add(Component, Jecs.pair(OnDelete, Remove)) local entity = world:entity() world:add(entity, Component) world:delete(Component) -- `Component` will be removed from `enttiy`

searchDocs.title: Nameâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.Name: Id An Id used for setting names on entities. local Name = Jecs.Name local alice = world:entity() world:set(alice, Name, "Alice")

searchDocs.title: Exclusiveâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.Exclusive: Id A Component Trait for marking relationships as exclusive, meaning that the entity can only ever have one target for the relation marked as exclusive, where the target is the second element of a pair.

searchDocs.title: componentâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.component() â†’Â Component<T> Preregisters a component, without a World.

searchDocs.title: tagâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.tag() â†’Â Component Preregisters a tag component, without a World.

searchDocs.title: metaâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.meta() â†’Â () Sets metadata onto a Component, without a World. local Name = Jecs.Name local Position = Jecs.component() Jecs.meta(Position, Name, "Position")

searchDocs.title: pairâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.pair() â†’Â Id Encodes two Ids into one, to represent a Relationship. local Likes = world:component() local alice = world:entity() local bob = world:entity() world:add(bob, Jecs.pair(Likes, alice)) For more information on pairs, read here.

searchDocs.title: worldâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Jecs.world() â†’Â World Creates a new World.

searchDocs.title: First-party Resourcesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Provided within the official Jecs repository.  How To JecsExamplesModules

searchDocs.title: Community Resourcesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: API ReferenceResourcesAddonsFAQ

searchDocs.title: Contributionsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Community Documentation is located in two places:  Under the docs directory. This is where our documentation pages on the site are hosted. You can find a "ðŸ–‰ Edit this page" button on all Docs Pages to make quick edits! Or, within our Moonwave doc comments in the source code. Look for the </> button on the API page to find doc comments!  Friendly reminder that Jecs has an first-party How To series which serves as a step-by-step introduction to how Jecs works and the reasons behind it's design. Does the topic you want to write already exist? Do you think it should? Consider contributing to the first-party documentation for Jecs first!  When writing doc comments, avoid modifying any source code (other than comments) and be sure to follow the Moonwave syntax!

searchDocs.title: Development toolsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: jabby A Jecs debugger with a string-based query language and entity editing capabilities. jecs_entity_visualiser A simple entity and component visualiser in the output. jecs_lifetime_tracker A tool for inspecting entity lifetimes.

searchDocs.title: Helpersâ€‹
searchDocs.content: jecs_ob Observers & Monitors for queries. hammer A set of utilities for Jecs.

searchDocs.title: Schedulersâ€‹
searchDocs.content: lockstep scheduler A simple fixed step system scheduler. rubine An ergonomic, runtime agnostic scheduler for Jecs jam Provides hooks and a scheduler that implements Jabby and a topographical runtime. planck An agnostic scheduler inspired by Bevy and Flecs, with core features including phases, pipelines, run conditions, and startup systems. Planck also provides plugins for Jabby, Matter Hooks, and more.

searchDocs.title: Networkingâ€‹
searchDocs.content: feces A generalized replication system for Jecs.

searchDocs.title: Inputâ€‹
searchDocs.content: axis An agnostic, simple and versatile input library for ECS.    Looking to add your Addon? Click "Edit this page"!

searchDocs.title: Learningâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Jecs Official ExamplesAn Introduction to ECS for Robloxians - @UkendioEntities, Components and Systems - Mark JordanWhy Vanilla ECS is not enough - Sander MertensFormalisation of Concepts behind ECS and Entitas - Maxim ZaksEntity Component System and Rendering - Our MachinerySpecs and Legion, two very different approaches to ECS - Cora SherratWhere are my Entities and Components - Sander MertensArchetypes and Vectorization - Sander MertensBuilding Games with Entity Relationships - Sander MertensWhy it is time to start thinking of games as databases - Sander MertensA Roadmap to Entity Relationships - Sander MertensMaking the most of Entity Identifiers - Sander MertensWhy Storing State Machines in ECS is a Bad Idea - Sander MertensECS back & forth - Michele CainiSparse Set - Geeks for GeeksTaking the Entity-Component-System Architecture Seriously - @alice-i-cecileOverwatch Gameplay Architecture and Netcode - Blizzard, GDCData-Oriented Design and C++ - Mike Acton, CppConUsing Rust for Game Development - Catherine West, RustConfCPU caches and why you should care - Scott Meyers, NDCBuilding a fast ECS on top of a slow ECS - @UnitOfTimeCulling the Battlefield: Data Oriented Design in Practice - DICE, GDCGame Engine Entity/Object Systems - Bobby AnguelovUnderstanding Data Oriented Design for Entity Component Systems - Unity GDCUnderstanding Data Oriented Design - UnityData Oriented Design - Richard FabianInteractive app for browsing systems of City Skylines 2 - @Captain-Of-CoitAwesome Entity Component System (link collection related to ECS) - Jeongseok LeeHibitset - DOCS.RS
